body.head.byline: Special to The New York Times

block.p: LEAD: In a rematch of the German Open final that Monica Seles won last month, top-seeded Steffi Graf will be matched against the 16-year-old from Yugoslavia in the French Open women's singles final Saturday.

LEAD: In a rematch of the German Open final that Monica Seles won last month, top-seeded Steffi Graf will be matched against the 16-year-old from Yugoslavia in the French Open women's singles final Saturday.

In a rematch of the German Open final that Monica Seles won last month, top-seeded Steffi Graf will be matched against the 16-year-old from Yugoslavia in the French Open women's singles final Saturday.

This year a more stylish Graf blazed through the draw here in her white headband and pearl-drop earrings without dropping a set. Graf, a two-time French Open champion who has lost only to Seles this year, has won eight of the last nine Grand Slam tournaments. Graf said she has a more positive attitude and is playing better now than she did in January when she won the Australian Open.

The only blemish to her Grand Slam record came here last year when Arantxa Sanchez Vicario of Spain upset her in a three-set final that followed a surprising semifinal in which Seles took a set from Graf.

Seles enters the final with the best record of any woman this year: she is 33-3 and has won 31 consecutive matches, a streak that includes victories against Graf and Martina Navratilova. In career meetings, however, Graf wields a 3-1 advantage over Seles.
